supporting.text: According to the standard order of operations (PEMDAS/BODMAS), multiplication is performed before addition, so 3 + 3 * 4 equals 3 + 12, which is 15.

attacks.text: According to the standard order of operations (PEMDAS/BODMAS), multiplication is performed before addition, so 3 + 3 * 4 equals 3 + 12, which is 15.
If addition is mistakenly performed before multiplication, the equation becomes (3 + 3) * 4 = 6 * 4 = 24, which does not equal 3 * 5 = 15.
The claim incorrectly assumes the equation holds true by ignoring the standard order of operations, leading to an invalid conclusion.

supporting.text: The right side of the equation, 3 * 5, equals 15, which matches the result of the left side when calculated correctly.

attacks.text: The right side of the equation, 3 * 5, equals 15, which matches the result of the left side when calculated correctly.
The left side of the equation, 3 + 3 * 4, equals 15 only if multiplication is performed before addition (following PEMDAS/BODMAS rules). Without this rule, the result would differ.
Standard arithmetic conventions (PEMDAS/BODMAS) are universally taught and accepted, ensuring consistent interpretation of such equations.
If interpreted left-to-right without operator precedence, 3 + 3 * 4 would equal 24, making the equation false.
Left-to-right interpretation contradicts mathematical standards and would lead to widespread inconsistency in calculations.

supporting.text: If addition were performed before multiplication, the left side would incorrectly evaluate to (3 + 3) * 4 = 6 * 4 = 24, which does not equal 15.

attacks.text: If addition were performed before multiplication, the left side would incorrectly evaluate to (3 + 3) * 4 = 6 * 4 = 24, which does not equal 15.
Standard arithmetic rules (PEMDAS/BODMAS) dictate that multiplication is performed before addition, making the original equation correct: 3 + (3 * 4) = 3 + 12 = 15.
In non-standard or ambiguous notation systems, the order of operations may not be universally clear, potentially leading to misinterpretation.

supporting.text: The equation holds true because both sides simplify to the same value (15) when the standard rules of arithmetic are followed.

attacks.text: The equation holds true because both sides simplify to the same value (15) when the standard rules of arithmetic are followed.
The equation does not hold true because the left side (3 + 3 * 4) evaluates to 15 only if multiplication is prioritized, while the right side (3 * 5) is unambiguously 15.
The standard order of operations (PEMDAS/BODMAS) dictates that multiplication is performed before addition, so the left side correctly evaluates to 15, matching the right side.
If addition were prioritized over multiplication, the left side would evaluate to 24, which does not match the right side, but this violates standard arithmetic rules.
